Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Would people rather mine BTCH with any recent CPU on the planet, or with newer fancy ASICs like the z9 and z9 mini? Discuss.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> They are two very different paths

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Berg> I personally believe that CPU ASIC resistance is the best yet, because it doesn't favor either of those two battling parties.
I'm still pretty on the fence between the two though, I'd like to see what the community has to say about it.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Berg> 
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/407861562108542988/484374012533932032/latest.png

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <gilardh> Question that I ask:
- How many CPUs in circulation against how many ASICs?
- What is the distribution / terrestrial distribution rate of CPUs compared to ASIC?
- Which one is the least dedicated to a single task between the CPU and the ASIC?
- What would be the best distribution / distribution for Block Reward, CPU or ASIC?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> Only Asic resistance will be better. POW/POS 50/50 like a veruscoin is very best decision

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> This is a good consensus giving the opportunity to earn coin holders and simple home miners, excluding large farms (there are many large not only ASIC farms but also GPUs)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Berg> I do agree that Verushash would really set BTCH apart from other Bitclones

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> BTCH will become a unique coin in the ranks of countless clones (BTCP, BTG, Bitcoin green, bitcoin interest)
None of them offers such a good fair option for ordinary people. You can say it can become a people's coin for people)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <KayNut> ASIC mining makes BTCH an exclusive coin for people that can, and are willing, to pay for ASIC miners. Whereas CPU mining makes it possible for the average Joe (me) to get some coins at small cost (electricity is expensive in germany). It (CPU mining) also would be a small step in mass adoption .

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> You are right. In European countries, electricity is expensive and there are few miners. Basically Asia, Russia, former socialist countries, and countries where cheap electricity. Our version is suitable for everyone. For people with any financial means and region of residence.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I also feel that VerusHash is more "fair" in that more people in the world already have CPUs that can mine it, and they are the cheapest way to mine versus GPU + ASIC, which require larger up-front investments. It allows old computers to be "up-cycled", all of a sudden an old dusty computer  can generate some funds. It also allows people in areas with no access to GPU cards or ASICs (a lot of people) to be able to mine the same way as everybody else. Equal access mining I guess.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> in theory the lead dev of Verus will send in a PR that will allow new KMD asset chains to choose VerusHash

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> when that happens, we can then use that option when we make the new BTCH chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> If BTCH becomes VerusHash 50/50, it will be very similar to Verus, in terms of the tech insides. Something to consider when thinking about marketing + differentiating the coins

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <heguli97> Then even someone with very little funds could go to a second hand store, buy a 20$ desktop an possibly make a profit.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the best scenario is repurposing existing computers to mine on a few cores, if they aren't using them all, or buying computers there are very cheap from a few years ago

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> for instance, mining on the very newest computers with VerusHash gives you a higher mining rate, but your cost per H/s is higher, because new hardware has a high premium

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the CPUs need to be made in the last ~5 years to effectively mine VerusHash, older computers will be able to do very slowly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> core i5's and newer are good, it's all about having certain CPU instructions (AES, AVX, and friends)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the more fast instructions your CPU has, and the faster they are, the better your hashrate

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if the CPU doesn't have them, verushash will still work but it doesn't make sense financially to mine in that situation

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> AMD + Intel CPU's work, in case that wasn't clear, anything reasonably new

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> i guess we can estimate the future mining potential of CPUs on BTCH by looking at Verus hashrates

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> conveniently, the Verus Discord has a channel just for that #cpu-hashrate

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> so look up your CPU version, and search for it in that channel to see other peoples speeds

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that will let you say "which of these 2 CPU's would be better at mining BTCH?" if you wanted to ask such a question.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Berg> If you'd like to go check out hash rates:
https://discord.gg/jXFvm8p

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> very good question

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> What usually attracts people first? In most cases, the opportunity to earn, get a bonus. The success of Veruscoin was that at the very beginning people had the opportunity to get coins in large quantities with little CPU power or the number of coins in the wallet, provided that the coin is strictly limited in quantity.
I would call it democratic

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> For example, can I make a CPU power limit? Or a limit on the maximum number of coins for POS mining, so as to exclude large players altogether? Socialism in Crypto

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> Now I see that the complexity of Veruscoin's network has greatly increased compared to when it started. Is it possible to do so that the interest was much longer. Perhaps this is a stupid question, just a reflection

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Some people remark that very early Verus investors staked a huge amount of coins, which pale in comparison to what you can mine now, if you read their #mining channel discord from today.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> The reason BTCH is considering PoS is to give something to current BTCH HODLers, to compensate for increasing supply and diluting the % of total supply that you own. The intent is to level the playing field between benefiting current HODLers and future miners. There doesn't seem to be a consensus about anything, just talking about options

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if we did, we would be using the builtin -ac_stake options to Komodo, where we can define the % of blocks that are PoS, so it could 50 or whatever we decide
